title: How to Keep Baking Flour Fresh

steps.headline: Buy only as much flour as you think you'll need.
steps.description: That way, you won't suffer from an oversupply with a potential for the flour to go stale or spoil.

steps.headline: Use suitable containers to maintain freshness.
steps.description: Airtight containers will help you to keep flour in great condition for longer. Use tall airtight containers that can be safely stored in your pantry or kitchen cupboards. Airtight containers preserve freshness and will stop insects from accessing the flour. However, if insect eggs were already in the flour, an infestation can occur but it will be contained within the container.

steps.headline: Fill the containers with flour.
steps.description: However, do not overfill so that they're too heavy for you to life. In that case, split the flour between containers.

steps.headline: Label the flour when storing it.
steps.description: That way you'll know how long it has been stored for and you know when it's nearing its best by date. The best by date will be on the package. Follow the advice give, realizing that after this date, while the flour is still edible, the flavor may taste stale. Label the exact flour type, for example, strong bread flour, plain/all-purpose flour, self raising/self rising flour, so that you're aware of the contents.

steps.headline: Bake often.
steps.description: Use flour often and you won't have to worry about spoilage as you'll be using it up well and truly before it is due to expire.

steps.headline: Keep flour in the refrigerator to help it stay fresh for longer.
steps.description: It can last for up to two years refrigerated.

steps.headline: Place the flour in an airtight container.
steps.description: Ensure that the lid has sealed entirely.

steps.headline: Place in the refrigerator.
steps.description: Keep it towards the back. That way, it won't get in the way of other more frequently accessed foods.

steps.headline: Keep flour in the freezer to preserve it longer.
steps.description: This is almost essential for wholemeal/wholewheat flour which contains a higher level of fat that can go rancid if not kept properly. Some of the effectiveness of self-raising or self-rising flour might be reduced from freezing.

steps.headline: Place the flour in an airtight container that is suitable for freezing.
steps.description: Ensure that the lid can't come off with ease.

steps.headline: Freeze.
steps.description: Most flour can be kept for a long time in the freezer.

text: Basics Buy only as much flour as you think you'll need. That way, you won't suffer from an oversupply with a potential for the flour to go stale or spoil. Use suitable containers to maintain freshness. Airtight containers will help you to keep flour in great condition for longer. Use tall airtight containers that can be safely stored in your pantry or kitchen cupboards. Airtight containers preserve freshness and will stop insects from accessing the flour. However, if insect eggs were already in the flour, an infestation can occur but it will be contained within the container. Fill the containers with flour. However, do not overfill so that they're too heavy for you to life. In that case, split the flour between containers. Label the flour when storing it. That way you'll know how long it has been stored for and you know when it's nearing its best by date. The best by date will be on the package. Follow the advice give, realizing that after this date, while the flour is still edible, the flavor may taste stale. Label the exact flour type, for example, strong bread flour, plain/all-purpose flour, self raising/self rising flour, so that you're aware of the contents. Bake often. Use flour often and you won't have to worry about spoilage as you'll be using it up well and truly before it is due to expire. Refrigerating flour Keep flour in the refrigerator to help it stay fresh for longer. It can last for up to two years refrigerated. Place the flour in an airtight container. Ensure that the lid has sealed entirely. Label and date the container.  Place in the refrigerator. Keep it towards the back. That way, it won't get in the way of other more frequently accessed foods. Freezing flour Keep flour in the freezer to preserve it longer. This is almost essential for wholemeal/wholewheat flour which contains a higher level of fat that can go rancid if not kept properly. Some of the effectiveness of self-raising or self-rising flour might be reduced from freezing. Place the flour in an airtight container that is suitable for freezing. Ensure that the lid can't come off with ease. Freeze. Most flour can be kept for a long time in the freezer.
